United States | type = [[Maritime museum]] | collection = | visitors = | director = | president = | curator = Joe Cavanaugh | publictransit = | network = | website = [http://www.pacificwarmuseum.org National Museum of the Pacific War] }} The '''National Museum of the Pacific War''' is located in [[Fredericksburg, Texas]], the boyhood home of [[Fleet Admiral (United States)|Fleet Admiral]] [[Chester W. Nimitz]]. Fleet Admiral Nimitz served as CinCPAC, Commander in Chief, United States Pacific Fleet during [[World War II]]. The six acre site includes the '''Admiral Nimitz Museum''' which is housed in the old Nimitz Hotel and tells the story of Fleet Admiral Nimitz beginning with his life as a young boy through his naval career as well as the evolution of the old hotel. ==Nimitz Hotel== [[Charles Henry Nimitz]], German merchant marine and grandfather of [[Fleet Admiral (United States)|Fleet Admiral]] [[Chester Nimitz]], was born in [[Bremen]] in [[Germany]]. He emigrated to the [[United States]] by way of [[South Carolina]] in 1844. In 1846, Nimitz moved to Fredericksburg with the initial settlers. In 1848, he married Sophie Dorothea Mueller, and nine of the couple's twelve children lived to adulthood.{{cite web|last=Kohout|first=Martin Donell|title=Nimitz, Charles Henry|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fni04|work=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=14 November 2010}} Local trouble maker James P. Waldrip tried unsuccessfully to recruit Nimitz into Die Haengebande.{{cite book|last=Adam|first=Thomas|title=Germany and the Americas: Culture, Politics, and History|year=2005|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-85109-628-2|page=384}} Charles Nimitz built the Nimitz Hotel in 1852, and deeded it over to his son Charles H. Nimitz, Jr., in 1906. Locals referred to it as the Steamboat Hotel because of the ship's bow front. The hotel had its own saloon and brewery, a ballroom that doubled as a theatre, a smokehouse, and a bath-house.{{cite book|last=Potter|first=E B|title=Nimitz (Potter)|year=1976|publisher=US Naval Institute Press|isbn=978-0-87021-492-9|page=23}} In its heyday, the hotel hosted such guests as [[Horace Greeley]], [[Johnny Ringo]], [[Rutherford B. Hayes|President Rutherford B. Hayes]], [[General]] [[Robert E. Lee]], [[General]] [[James Longstreet]], [[General]] [[Phil Sheridan]], [[William Sydney Porter]] and [[General]] [[Ulysses S. Grant]].{{cite book|last=Jamison|first=Cheryl|title=Texas Home Cooking|year=1993|publisher=Harvard Common Press|isbn=978-1-55832-059-8|page=501}}{{cite book|last=Johnson|first=David|title=John Ringo|year=1996|publisher=Barbed Wire Pr|isbn=978-0-935269-23-9|page=78}}{{cite book|last=Larrabee|first=Eric|title=Commander in Chief: Franklin Delano Roosevelt, His Lieutenants, and Their War |year=2004|publisher=US Naval Institute Press|isbn=978-1-59114-455-7|page=355}}{{cite book|last=Carmack|first=Liz|title=Historic Hotels of Texas: A Traveler's Guide |year=2007|publisher=TAMU Press|isbn=978-1-58544-608-7|page=236}}{{cite web|author=Kohout, Martin Donell |title=Nimitz Hotel |url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/ccn01 |work=Handbook of Texas Online. Texas State Historical Association |accessdate=11 November 2012}} Anna Henke Nimitz, the wife of his son Chester Bernard Nimitz became pregnant with their only child Chester William Nimitz. The senior Chester died before his son was born on February 24, 1885. Little Chester's grandfather Charles served as a father figure the first five years of his life. In 1890, the widow Nimitz married her husband's brother William Nimitz and moved with him to [[Kerrville, Texas|Kerrville]] where he managed the St. Charles Hotel. While still a teenager, Chester was accepted for enrollment in the [[United States Naval Academy]], where he graduated seventh out of a class of 114. Chester Nimitz rose to the rank of Commander-in-Chief of the U.S. Pacific Forces in [[World War II]]. Fleet Admiral Nimitz died February 20, 1966.{{cite web|last=Weddle|first=Robert S|title=Nimitz, Chester William|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fni05|work=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association}} The Nimitz Hotel was designated a [[Recorded Texas Historic Landmark]] in 1989, Marker number 10089.{{cite web|title=Nimitz Hotel|url=http://www.9key.com/markers/marker_detail.asp?atlas_number=5171010089|work=Recorded Texas Historic Marker|publisher=William Nienke, Sam Morrow|accessdate=13 February 2011}} ==The Museum== The Admiral Nimitz Foundation was established in 1964 (as the Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz Naval Museum, Inc.) to support a museum honoring Fredericksburg’s native son, Commander-in-Chief of Allied Forces, Pacific Ocean Area. [[File:Nmpw-front-left-flags.jpg|thumb|left|The entrance to the National Museum of the Pacific War]] The hotel owned by Nimitz's grandfather Charles Henry Nimitz was restored to its original design and renamed the Admiral Nimitz Museum by an act of the Texas legislature in 1968.{{cite web|title=National Museum of the Pacific War{{!}} Museum Beginnings|url=http://www.pacificwarmuseum.org/our-story/beginnings/}} The original intent was to focus only as a memorial to Fleet Admiral Chester Nimitz.{{cite web|title=Natl Museum of the Pacific War|url=http://www.texastouristguide.com/Articles/National_Museum_of_the_Pacific_War.asp|publisher=Texas Tourist Guide|accessdate=23 December 2010}} In 2000, the complex was renamed Admiral Nimitz State Historic Site - National Museum of the Pacific War and is dedicated exclusively to the Pacific Theater battles of World War II.{{cite journal|last=Hallowell|first=John|title=Fredericksburg's Nimitz Museum|journal=Texas Hill Country Magazine|year=2007|issue=Fall}} The conning tower of {{USS|Pintado|SS-387}} is at the main museum entrance.[http://www.navsource.org/archives/08/08387.htm NavSource Naval History USS Pintado Photo Page] The Pacific Combat Zone is a re-creation of a Pacific island battlefield, and includes a Quonset hut hospital, a PT boat and base, Japanese tank, palm trees, and machine gun placements. Re-enactments, called [http://www.pacificwarmuseum.org/your-visit/living-history/ Living History] exhibits, are held throughout the year.{{cite news|last=Brandt|first=Terry|title=Town Zeroing in on Tourism with Military Flair|newspaper=Amarillo Globe News|date=7 December 2003}} The Veterans' [http://www.pacificwarmuseum.org/get-involved/memorials/ Walk of Honor and Memorial Wall] can be found within the Memorial Courtyard.{{cite book|last=Forehand|first=J C R|title=The German Soldier that Sergeant York Never Met|year=2010|publisher=Tate Publishing|isbn=978-1-61663-950-1|page=144}} On May 8, 1976, the 130th anniversary of the founding of Fredericksburg, the Japanese government gifted the museum with the Japanese Garden of Peace. The garden was designed by Taketora Saita as a replica of the private garden of ''[[Gensui (Imperial Japanese Navy)|Gensui]]'' The [[Marquis]] [[Tōgō Heihachirō|Tōgō]] (1848–1934), the main [[Imperial Japanese Navy]] commander in the [[Russo-Japanese War]].{{cite web|title=Togo Heihachiro|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/598103/Togo-Heihachiro|work=Encyclopædia Britannica Online|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica|accessdate=23 December 2010}} Fleet Admiral Nimitz personally admired the [[Marquis]] Tōgō, having previously helped to establish a war memorial to the Japanese admiral.{{cite journal|title=Garden of Peace-Fredericksburg|journal=Texas Monthly|date=August 1991|page=112}}{{cite web|last=Kohout|first=Martin Donell|title=National Museum of the Pacific War|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/gkn02|work=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=23 December 2010}} [[File:Plaza of the Presidents Nimitz Museum.jpg|thumb|Plaza of the Presidents on the Museum grounds]] The outdoor Plaza of the Presidents was dedicated on September 2, 1995, the 50th anniversary of Fleet Admiral Nimitz' acceptance of the [[Japanese Instrument of Surrender]] aboard the {{USS|Missouri|BB-63}}. The plaza is a tribute to the ten [[President of the United States|United States Presidents]] who served during World War II: [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] (Commander in Chief), [[Harry S Truman]] (Commander in Chief), [[General of the Army (United States)|General of the Army]] [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] (Army), [[John F. Kennedy]] (Navy), [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] (Navy), [[Richard Nixon]] (Navy), [[Gerald Ford]] (Navy), [[Jimmy Carter]] (Navy), [[Ronald Reagan]] (Army) and [[George H. W. Bush]] (Navy).{{cite web|title=Plaza of the Presidents|url=http://www.pacificwarmuseum.org/PlazaOfPresidents.asp|publisher=Pacific War Museum|accessdate=23 December 2010}}{{cite book|last=Naylor|first=June|title=Quick Escapes Dallas/Fort Worth, 6th: Getaways in and around the Lone Star State |year=2008|publisher=GPP Travel|isbn=978-0-7627-4558-6|page=87}} [[George H.W. Bush]] cut the ribbon in 1991 for the $3 million gallery bearing his name. The George H.W. Bush Gallery is home to an [[Imperial Japanese Navy|I.J.N.]] [[Ko-hyoteki class submarine|Ko-hyoteki class midget submarine]] (which participated in the attack on [[Pearl Harbor]]), a Japanese [[Kawanishi N1K]] "Rex" floatplane, and an American [[North American B-25 Mitchell]]. In 1991, the land for the Bush Gallery was bought from [[H-E-B|H-E-B Grocery]]. Money for the gallery was privately raised in the 1990s through the efforts of finance chairman Lee Bass and a board that included [[baseball]] star [[Nolan Ryan]] and Ernest Angelo, a former [[mayor]] of [[Midland, Texas|Midland]]. Admission tickets cover both museums. Bush later reflected that "terrifying experiences" of war helped him to become a man: "I have often wondered why me, why was I spared when others died."Museum exhibit, Pacific Gallery, Fredericksburg, Texas On December 7, 2009 the museum hosted the Grand Re-Opening of the newly expanded George H. W. Bush Gallery where the second floor houses the Nimitz Education and Research Center. [[George H. W. Bush|Former President George H. W. Bush]] his wife [[Barbara Bush|Barbara]], along with [[Rick Perry|Texas Governor Rick Perry]], cut the ribbon. The ceremony was attended by survivors of the [[Attack on Pearl Harbor]], and drew a crowd of 5,000 people.{{cite news|title=George H.W. Bush Opens New War Museum|newspaper=United Press International, Inc|date=8 December 2009}} ==See also== *[[List of museums in Central Texas]] * [[National D-Day Memorial]] * [[National World War II Memorial]] * [[National World War II Museum]] * [[USMC War Memorial|United States Marine Corps War Memorial]] (Iwo Jima) * [[List of Texas state historic sites]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://www.nimitzfoundation.org Admiral Nimitz Foundation Website] {{Protected Areas of Texas}} [[Category:Texas state historic sites]] [[Category:Maritime museums in Texas]] [[Category:Military and war museums in Texas]] [[Category:Naval museums in the United States]] [[Category:Museums in Gillespie County, Texas]] [[Category:Biographical museums in Texas]] [[Category:Recorded Texas Historic Landmarks]] [[Category:World War II museums in the United States]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Fredericksburg, Texas]] [[Category:Museums established in 1969]] [[Category:1969 establishments in Texas]] [[Category:Japanese gardens in the United States]]
